title: 110_s3427
content: The "Costal Homeowners Assistance Act" may be cited as the short title. It introduces a nonrefundable personal credit for hurricane mitigation property under the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The "Costal Homeowners Assistance Act" introduces a nonrefundable personal credit for hurricane mitigation property expenditures. Eligible individuals can receive a credit equal to 25 percent of qualified expenses, not exceeding $5,000 or the total tax liability for the year. The "Costal Homeowners Assistance Act" offers a nonrefundable personal credit for hurricane mitigation property expenses. Eligible individuals can get a credit equal to 25% of qualified expenses, up to $5,000 or the total tax liability for the year. An eligible individual is defined as a taxpayer whose main residence is in an area designated for federal assistance due to hurricanes in 2004 or 2005, or in a county bordering the Atlantic Ocean or Gulf of Mexico. Qualified hurricane mitigation property expenditures include improving roof deck attachment, creating a secondary water barrier, enhancing roof covering durability, bracing gable-end walls, reinforcing roof-to-wall connection, protecting openings from windborne debris, safeguarding exterior doors and garages, and other mitigation purposes as specified by the Secretary in regulations. The Secretary, in consultation with the Administrator of FEMA, sets regulations for qualified hurricane mitigation property expenditures in the taxpayer's main residence. Expenditures must be approved by a State-certified inspector, and labor costs for onsite preparation are included. Expenditures for inspection costs related to the preparation, assembly, or installation of qualified hurricane mitigation property are considered in determining taxpayer's expenses. Definitions for "principal residence" and "qualified dwelling unit" are provided in this section. The curr_chunk discusses amendments to various sections of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986, specifically adding references to section 25E. These changes are related to tax credits for qualified dwelling units. Amendments to the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 include adding references to section 25E for tax credits related to qualified dwelling units. The amendments made by this section include a credit for home insurance premium increases, applicable to taxable years starting after December 31, 2007. An eligible individual can receive a tax credit equal to 50% of qualified homeowners insurance premium increases, not exceeding $5,000. Eligible individuals are taxpayers with a principal residence in an area designated for federal assistance under the Stafford Act. The Disaster Relief and Emergency Assistance Act provides tax credits for homeowners affected by hurricanes in 2004 or 2005, or in high-risk counties with increased insurance premiums in 2004, 2005, or 2006. Eligible individuals can receive a tax credit equal to 50% of qualified homeowners insurance premium increases, not exceeding $5,000, if their principal residence is within 100 miles of the designated federal assistance area under the Stafford Act. The term "qualified homeowners insurance premium increase" refers to the percentage increase in the premium for homeowners insurance on the third policy anniversary date following the applicable date for eligible individuals. The "qualifying percentage" is the excess percentage points of the premium increase between the last policy anniversary before the applicable date and the third policy anniversary date. The term "applicable date" refers to the date before a determination for individuals in specific areas, and for individuals in certain counties, it is September 1, 2005. "Homeowners insurance" includes coverage for a principal residence. The term "principal residence" includes coverage for wind damage through a State-run wind pool. A "qualified dwelling unit" is assessed at less than $1,000,000 and qualifies for a tax credit. The credit is treated as a personal nonrefundable credit under the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The tax credit allowed under this section is limited based on the amount of tax for a taxable year. If the credit exceeds the limitation imposed by the Internal Revenue Code of 1986, it can be carried forward to future years. The tax credit allowed can be carried forward to future years if it exceeds the limitation imposed by the Internal Revenue Code of 1986.
